title: Epic: Refactor TalkBack into Developer-Friendly Accessibility Testing Service
description:
Transform TalkBack into an AccessibilityService designed for integration testing and agentic automation. Enable programmatic gesture control over ADB, improve debugging fixtures, and create visualization tools for accessibility trees.

Goals:
- Move away from MCP server approach to a more ambitious developer-friendly system
- Enable programmatic testing of accessibility features
- Provide rich debugging and visualization tools
- Support agentic/automated testing workflows

Phases:
1. Core accessibility service refactor
2. ADB interface for programmatic control
3. Enhanced debugging fixtures
4. Visualization tools (stretch: 3D WebGL a11y tree viewer)

This epic will contain multiple sub-issues for each phase.

title: Phase 1: Audit existing TalkBack codebase and identify core service components
description:
Before refactoring, we need to understand the current TalkBack architecture:
- Map out existing AccessibilityService implementation
- Identify gesture handling logic
- Document current event processing pipeline
- List dependencies and components that need refactoring
- Create architecture diagram of current state

Deliverable: Architecture document with component map and refactor strategy
close_reason: Comprehensive architecture audit complete. Created detailed documentation at docs/architecture/CURRENT_ARCHITECTURE.md covering all major subsystems: event pipeline, gesture handling, focus management, actors, and refactoring strategy.

title: Phase 4 (Stretch): Add HTML accessibility reports and diagnostics
description:
Generate HTML reports from a11y tree data:
- Static HTML reports with tree visualization
- Accessibility issue detection and reporting
- Best practice violations
- Coverage metrics (labeled elements, contrast, etc.)
- Historical comparison (track improvements)
- Integration with CI/CD for automated a11y checks
- Shareable reports for team review

Complement the 3D view with actionable diagnostics

title: Phase 1: Extract core AccessibilityService into testable module
description:
Refactor TalkBack's AccessibilityService into a clean, testable module:
- Separate UI/feedback logic from core accessibility logic
- Create interfaces for gesture handling
- Make event processing pipeline injectable/mockable
- Remove dependencies on TalkBack-specific UI components
- Ensure service can run in test mode without full TalkBack UI

Goal: Core service that can be instantiated and controlled programmatically

title: Phase 2: Design ADB protocol for accessibility control commands
description:
Define the protocol for controlling the accessibility service over ADB:
- Command schema (JSON/protobuf?)
- Gesture commands (tap, swipe, multi-touch, etc.)
- Query commands (get a11y tree, get element properties)
- Event subscription (stream accessibility events)
- Response format and error handling
- Authentication/security model for ADB connection

Deliverable: Protocol specification and examples

title: Phase 1: Validate Gradle build system works
description:
Ensure the project builds successfully with Gradle before making any changes:
- Run ./gradlew build to verify clean build
- Check all modules compile (talkback, utils, braille, etc.)
- Identify build configuration and dependencies
- Document build process
- Ensure CI/CD integration works if applicable

This validates we have a working baseline before refactoring.

title: Write developer documentation and examples

description:

- Event recording/playback for regression tests

Make it easy to write and debug accessibility tests

title: Phase 4 (Stretch): Export accessibility tree to web-friendly format
description:

- Include screen coordinates, bounds, hierarchy

Feed data to the 3D visualization frontend

title: Phase 2: Implement accessibility tree query API over ADB
description:
Enable querying the a11y tree structure via ADB:
- Export full accessibility tree as structured data
- Query by selector (role, text, content-description)
- Get node properties (bounds, state, actions)
- Navigate tree relationships (parent, children, siblings)
- Performance optimization for large trees
- Snapshot/diff capability

Critical for test assertions and agentic navigation

title: Phase 2: Implement ADB bridge service for command handling
description:
Build the ADB interface layer:
- ADB socket server in the accessibility service
- Command parser and dispatcher
- Response serialization
- Error handling and logging
- Security/permission checks
- Connection lifecycle management

Enable programmatic control via 'adb shell' or 'adb forward'

title: Phase 2: Implement programmatic gesture injection via ADB
description:
Build gesture control API accessible over ADB:
- Tap at coordinates
- Swipe gestures (direction, velocity, multi-finger)
- Long press, double tap
- Complex gesture sequences
- Gesture timing control
- Coordinate system handling (screen vs window)

Allow agents/tests to drive UI interactions programmatically

title: Phase 3: Build debugging UI for live inspection
description:
Create debug panel/overlay for live inspection:
- Show current accessibility tree state
- Highlight focused elements
- Display event stream in real-time
- Show gesture recognition debug info
- Performance metrics overlay
- Toggle between debug/production modes
- Remote inspection via web interface?

Helps developers understand what the service sees

title: Phase 3: Add structured logging and diagnostics system
description:
Implement comprehensive logging for debugging:
- Structured log format (JSON/logcat tags)
- Log levels and filtering
- Event tracing with timestamps
- Performance metrics (latency, throughput)
- Memory/resource usage tracking
- Log export via ADB
- Integration with Android Studio profiler

Enable deep visibility into a11y service behavior

title: Phase 4 (Stretch): Design 3D WebGL accessibility tree visualization
description:
Create an innovative 3D visualization of how TalkBack sees the screen:
- WebGL-based renderer for a11y tree
- Layered 3D cards representing UI hierarchy
- Spatial layout reflecting screen position + z-index
- Visual encoding of node properties (role, state, actions)
- Interactive navigation (rotate, zoom, select nodes)
- Highlight traversal order and focus flow
- Color-code issues (missing labels, poor contrast, etc.)

Goal: Help developers understand the accessibility tree structure spatially, similar to how Chrome DevTools shows the DOM but in 3D with accessibility context

title: Phase 4 (Stretch): Implement WebGL 3D renderer for a11y trees
